discourse_list.title: So is someone going to say anything about yesterday's FLAP auctions?

content.content: Yesterday was the tail of two auction houses. You had auctions 2.0 casually dumping $130MM onto the market without a miss and the Flapper giving away maker for essentially free. Losing who knows how much money in the process. Peep that 100% slippage…  Capture1548×345 22.1 KB  I don’t know how there is not already black thursday style thread of maker holders complaining about it TBH. It certaily shakes any confidence I’ve ever had in MKR seeing it piss away even more money. What is engineering doing about this?

Andy_McCall:  Losing who knows how much money in the process.   According to my data, the loss was around 2.47M or about 16%. Then there is also talk of Rune having settled a lot of these auctions and vowing to pay back the diff. If so, this covers about half the loss I think.
Would also note many were using makerburn to monitor the flaps and they were not on the dash so no intervention was made among some of the smaller users. Assuming that won’t happen again?
It won’t. Undelying issue has been fixed. Also, missing flap auctions have been recovered.

So is someone going to say anything about yesterday’s FLAP auctions?  Yep, I imagine so… on Monday. A lot of us spent the lions share of their Friday evening and night trying to prevent this from going worse.

Few thoughts Glad @LongForWisdom posted on the forums during the attack. Based on that I was able to participate and bid up an auction. Overall as a short term fix. I think that DAO simply needs to limit how many FLAP auctions can be kicked at one time.  Say 5 or 10. There is no urgency in settling Flap’s as they are system surpluses.  The issue was that 400+ auctions hit the market at once. On the positive note. Glad oracles, PE and Gov Alpha took their vested dai ($2,535,453) when they did as it saved potentially more dai from hitting the market in this flap auction attack. It also lowered the DAO’s liabilities.

Is it just me that thinks this is being blown out of all proportion? The “losses” (not really losses, since this was surplus generated by liquidation penalties), were one or two million. The system held up pretty well to an unprecedented event. Sure it could have been a lot worse if Rune wasn’t around to save the day, but to be honest, that points to a problem that goes way beyond a few flap auctions. How can it be that a project which describes itself as a decentralized autonomous organization simply falls apart if its founder isn’t around to save the day? I can’t help but feel the project has too many commentators/micro-managers, and not enough good builders, keepers, developers, etc.

I wouldn’t coinsider $2M+ small. But I agree overall the system held up well. It could have been a lot worse Just noting, based on @simonr0204 posting history before the attack he seems to consistently be lobbying against any changes to the status quo of the Flap auctions.

Zarevok:  Glad @LongForWisdom posted on the forums during the attack. Based on that I was able to participate and bid up an auction.   Ah, I’m glad that was helpful. I’d hoped it might bring in a few more bids, but nice to hear it confirmed. The link went up on reddit and I believe a few people tweeted it as well.

I’m not trying to make a point about flap auctions either way. I guess in general I advocate (“lobby” is, in my humble opinion, not very generous), for a more strategic, less “tinkering” approach. Especially since a growing proportion of people who propose changes to the system are, to extend a generous term of my own, “non-technical”.

I understand the losses were frustrating and hindsight really is 20-20 but the fix for this problem is a lot easier than the fix for Black Thursday’s issues. And while losing 2M DAI or so is not optimal, it is also a long way away from the disaster that occurred on Black Thursday. There is a discussion on Discord on how to limit the number of simultaneous flap auctions and that should fix the problem with no further side effects. The heartening thing was seeing the collateral auctions go off without a hitch in the midst of this market insanity.

First, note problems that have happened in the past which didn’t happen this time.  The Dai stayed at $1 Large volume of collateral liquidations went well  I think everyone knew that we’d be better off with Liquidations 2.0 style surplus auctions, but there were other priorities. Remedies (in order of how quick/easy they are):  Raise Surplus Buffer (i.e. disable flaps temporarily) Rate limit surplus auctions (e.g. 5-10 at a time) Liquidation 2.0 style surplus auctions

There should probably be an org-wide postmortem on the process failures that led to this, and I don’t want to jump the gun too much with my own perspective here. But since I’m apparently writing this post anyway: the risk of this sort of event has been known for a long time and repeatedly brought up, particularly but not exclusively by members of the Risk and PE teams. We got into a “worst of both worlds” scenario where a subset MKR holders strongly wished to continue burning in the short term, but no one pushed hard for auction improvements. The technical teams probably should have been more vocal about the risks; MKR holders probably should have given more weight to those risks when brought up. For example, if you read the replies to this recent signal request, you’ll see that many within the community were aware of the issue of low competition in Flap auctions, but the discussion failed to spur any policy or priority changes despite a clear (IMO) conclusion that continuing to flap under current conditions was unsafe:    [Signal Request] Adjust minimum bid increase(beg) and lot size (bump) on flap-auctions Signal Archive       Overview:  Over the past month we have seen the burn kick back into action. This has given us some data as to the efficiency of the burn auctions and how the system handles burns over some time. Examining the data it is shown that there is some inefficiencies when it comes to how we buy back MKR. For the auctions in November/December 2021 the average price of bought MKR was 3,62% over market price and the median was 3,47%. Due to a few outliers the median seems to give the more correct picture.  …     In short, this was a systemic malfunction due to competing priorities and underweighting of risks.  What is engineering doing about this?  PECU doesn’t have the kind of mandate from governance that is required to just “do something”. I, as a PECU member, recommend that burns be turned off in the short term and a more robust mechanism be put in place before they are resumed (there are many good options for this, including some pretty low-hanging ones, like throughput limitations–the roadblocks are not technical). As soon as governance can reach some consensus on the path forward, action can be taken.

Kurt_Barry:  I, as a PECU member, recommend that burns be turned off in the short term   And the quickest option for this is what? Get the DAO to stop with the buffer lerp-ing and raise the buffer to infinity?

Yes, that is the quickest option. It would require an executive vote, so the minimum timeline to get it in place is roughly 1 week, unless the DAO wants to accelerate the usual governance cycle (although even then it takes at least 3-4 days to be effective, due to the governance delay and the time needed to ready the spell and get delegates/MKR holders to vote on it).

As much as I love burns, they have little to no effect at this point based on market sentiment— seems to have been that way for a while. The funds could be better deployed at this stage of Maker. Burns were the first, OG tokenomics but much has been developed since then. Once there are some better mechanics we should resume. Thanks for the analysis!

Spent a moderate amount of eth doing my part - won no auctions but at least bought time for others with more MKR than I had free to come in. Definitely need to address flapper mechanics generally. I think a discussion on how we could better approach both funding various buying facilities (not just MKR but ETH for oracle fees) as well as setting up multiple mechanisms to apply this funding is in order.  setting limit orders DCA market buying on exchanges (say Uniswap or others) at some fixed amount of DAI or with some maximum price (where it will stop) funding such a beast with some % of liquidation fees (automatically) so some buying kicks off when markets are stressed but with a controlled DAI rate and maximum price.  Maker governance had to pause the MKR flops during/after BT (because of insufficient liquidity) and now it makes sense to basically halt MKR flaps until we can put into place an entirely better buying model that doesn’t just include MKR but also ETH for protocol fees.   I really think this is illustrative of how the protocol really doesn’t do well managing both the buying or selling of MKR. I look forward to the discussion on this and for now given the current situation I am strongly supportive of changing the SB parameters so basically we don’t flap until governance has a solution, and Engineering teams can implement it.

MakerDAO really need to prioritize this rapidly because from my seat here I see this market likely testing 1.7K on ETH possibly in as little as a few days and if we break that all hell could break loose. I also have concerns Maker is not prepared with any sort of market cascading liquidation emergency contingencies much less conditions where these emergency contingencies would be triggered.

Kurt_Barry:  In short, this was a systemic malfunction due to competing priorities and underweighting of risks   I would like to offer a little push back on this particular statement. In my opinion the protocol took a calculated risk that backfired. From the thread that was posted that shows that the risks were known, it also shows that the consensus for the proper solution was the introduction of liq2.0 for surplus auctions. Liq2.0 for surplus auctions are in the pipeline. Given the likely efficiency loss from surplus auctions the assessment was that the opportunity cost of prioritizing liq2.0 over other engineering projects were higher than the expected gains of implementing liq2.0. In an uncertain world you have to put in your priorities and play the odds. Sometimes the dice doesn’t turn out in your favor. That doesn’t necessarily mean you undervalued the risk.

@Kurt_Barry is there a world where the protocol could get away from sending DAI to to the Flapper via lerping the SB? I.e is there some world where lets say 1MM dai per day is sent to the burner and that amount is just subtracted from the current SB? It seems to me that has been the direction the DAO wants to lean with all of the buffer lerping and maybe just explicitly making that the rule makes more sense. And is this the right time to be talking about such an “improvement?”
Great discussion! Wanted to add some comments and updates on the state of auction UIs. Check it out here: On the State of the Auctions UIs

Of course there’s such a world–one where MKR holders commit to this strategy and the technical teams implement it. Is now the right time? Well, that depends–if MKR holders want to keep burning, now is absolutely the time to make such a change, particularly since the risks of the prior strategy are finally being appreciated.
